questions.solution:
Moll glands are examples of apocrine sweat gland.

Moll glands are present in the eyelid. They are a type of modified apocrine sweat glands opening either into a lash follicle or directly onto the anterior lid margin between the lashes.

Zeis glands are a type of modified sebaceous glands associated with lash follicles. Meibomian glands are modified sebaceous glands found in the tarsal plates.

questions.text: A patient presented with a painless swelling and watering in his left eye. Examination revealed the following finding. Which of the following statements is false regarding his diagnosis?

choices.text: It needs to be surgically treated.
It does not have malignant potential.
It is a chronic lipogranulomatous inflammation.

questions.solution:
A painless swelling on the lower lid is suggestive of a chalazion (tarsal cyst/meibomian cyst). It has the malignant potential to become an adenocarcinoma of the meibomian gland. 

Chalazion is the chronic lipogranulomatous inflammation (option D) of the meibomian gland (option B). It presents as painless swelling of the eyelid. It is more common in adults than children. Treatment includes incision and curettage (option B) and intralesional injection of triamcinolone acetate.

questions.text: A recurrent chalazion should be subjected to histopathological evaluation to exclude the possibility of _____.
questions.solution:
A recurrent chalazion should be subjected to histopathological evaluation to exclude the possibility of sebaceous gland carcinoma.

Note: A chalazion can undergo malignant change into sebaceous gland carcinoma (adenocarcinoma of meibomian gland).

Recurrences of chalazia are not uncommon. However, the physician should entertain the possibility of malignancy in such cases and should biopsy a lesion that recurs or appears atypical. The pathologist should be alerted to the suspicion of sebaceous gland carcinoma and frozen sections and lipid stains should be requested.

questions.text: A patient presented to the clinic with severe left eye pain, watering, and swelling of the lid for 2 days. He says it's difficult to see the laptop screen while working and he is unable to complete his daily targets. On examination, tender swelling is noted as shown below. What is the cause of this finding?
questions.solution:
The patient has acute presentation and painful swelling in the palpebral conjunctiva as shown in the image, suggestive of internal hordeolum. It is an acute suppurative inflammation of the meibomian gland associated with blockage of the duct.

Other options: 

Options A and B: Hordeolum externum or stye is the acute staphylococcal infection of the hair follicle/Zeis gland/Moll gland.

Option D: Chalazion is a chronic non-suppurative lipogranulomatous inflammation of the Meibomian gland.

questions.text: What is the length of the nasolacrimal duct?
questions.solution:
The nasolacrimal duct is 12–18 mm long.  

The lacrimal drainage system consists of the lacrimal sac, which is 10–12 mm long. It lies in the lacrimal fossa, between the anterior and posterior lacrimal crests. The lacrimal bone and the frontal process of the maxilla separate the lacrimal sac from the middle meatus of the nasal cavity.

The nasolacrimal duct is the inferior continuation of the lacrimal sac. It is 12–18 mm long and is directed downwards, backward, and laterally. The opening of the duct into the inferior meatus is partially covered by a mucosal fold (valve of Hasner).

The puncta are openings on the lid margin. There are two canaliculi from the puncta. Each canaliculus (superior and inferior) has two parts: Vertical (2 mm) and horizontal (8 mm). The superior and inferior canaliculi usually unite to form the common canaliculus, which opens into the lateral wall of the lacrimal sac. A small flap of mucosa (Rosenmüller valve) overhangs the junction of the common canaliculus and the lacrimal sac and prevents the reflux of tears into the canaliculi.

The image below shows structures of the lacrimal apparatus.

questions.text: Where does the nasolacrimal duct open?
questions.solution:
The nasolacrimal duct opens into the inferior meatus.

The nasolacrimal duct is the inferior continuation of the lacrimal sac. It is 12–18 mm long and is directed downwards, backward, and laterally. The opening of the duct into the inferior meatus is partially covered by a mucosal fold, called the valve of Hasner. The valve of Hasner prevents reflux from the nose.

questions.text: A 60-year-old woman came for an eye exam due to a gritty sensation that has been causing her a lot of discomfort. On examination, Rose Bengal staining is positive. She is diagnosed with keratoconjunctivitis sicca. Which of the following layer of the tear film is deficient in this condition?
questions.solution:
Keratoconjunctivitis sicca is due to the deficiency of the aqueous layer of the tear film.

In keratoconjunctivitis sicca, patients present with irritation and foreign body sensation. Marginal tear strip is reduced. The conjunctiva become dry and lustreless with positive Rose Bengal staining. Causes of keratoconjunctivitis sicca:

  • Sjogren's syndrome (primary keratoconjunctivitis sicca)
  • Non-Sjogren's keratoconjunctivitis sicca
    • Primary age-related hyposecretion (most common)
    • Lacrimal gland deficiencies - congenital, infiltration by tumors or sarcoidosis, surgical removal
    • Lacrimal gland duct obstruction - old trachoma, burns,  SJS
    • Reflex hyposecretion (neurogenic causes) - Parkinson disease, 7th nerve palsy, reflex sensory block

Hyperosmolarity of the tear film in dry eye disease leads to a cascade of signaling events that releases inflammatory mediators and leads to damage to the ocular surface which may further decrease tear film stability, leading to self-perpetuation of the disease in a "vicious circle".

Related Pearl: Layers of the Tear Film

Lipid layer

  • Outermost layer
  • Secreted by the meibomian, Zeis glands
  • Prevents evaporation of tears

Aqueous layer

  • Middle layer
  • Secreted by the lacrimal and accessory lacrimal glands
  • Provides lubrication

Mucin layer  

  • Innermost layer
  • Secreted by the goblet cells of the conjunctiva
  • Help in spreading the tear film over the ocular surface

The maximum density of the goblet cells is seen on the nasal bulbar conjunctiva.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true regarding the phenol red test for dry eye?

choices.text: It measures tear production based on the length of colour change in the thread
If color changes to blue, it depicts mucin deficiency.

questions.solution:
Phenol red test measures the tear production according to the length of colour change in the thread.

In phenol red test, the alkalinity of tears changes its colour to bright orange on contact. It doesn't require anaesthesia (unlike Schirmer's test). Three millimetres of a fine dye-impregnated 75-mm cotton thread is placed under the lateral one-fifth of the inferior palpebral lid margin for 15 seconds.

Based on length of colour change,

  •  >20 mm - normal tear production     
  •  10 to 19 mm - borderline dry eye     
  •  <10 mm - severe dry eye

The image shows a tear strip placed in the lower lid of the eye. This is the Schirmer test which is used to check for dry eye.

Dry eye is a multifactorial disease of the eye characterised by loss of homeostasis of the tear film. Patients present with irritation, foreign body sensation and dryness. Treatment of dry eye includes medical treatment (lubricating eyedrops, most commonly methylcellulose derivatives) or surgical treatment (lacrimal punctum occlusion using silicone plugs).

Other tests for dry eye include: 

  1. Tear film break-up test is used to determine the interval between a complete blink and appearance of first randomly distributed dry spot on the cornea. A drop of fluorescein is instilled in the eye, following by examination in the cobalt-blue light of a slit-lamp.
  2. Rose Bengal staining is used for the detection of dry, dead epithelium in dry eye.
  3. Tear osmolarity test is performed with an osmometer. 

Other options:

Option B: Ishihara plates are used to test colour vision. They help detect red-green colour blindness. 

Option C: Jones test is used in watering eye. It uses fluorescein dye. 

Option D: Goldmann's tonometry is used to measure intra-ocular pressure. It consists of a double prism mounted on a slit-lamp.  

Related Pearl: Tear film tests used for the diagnosis of dry eye

Schirmer test

Inference 

  • 15 mm: Normal
  • 5-10 mm: Moderate keratoconjunctivitis sicca (KCS)
  • < 5 mm: Severe KCS

Tear film break up test (TBUT)

Inference 

  • 15-35 seconds: Normal
  • < 10 seconds: Unstable tear film

Rose Bengal staining

Inference

  • A pattern: Confluent staining → Severe KCS
  • B pattern: Extensive staining → Moderate KCS
  • C pattern: Fine punctate stains → Mild KCS

Tear osmolarity test

Abnormal osmolarity is defined by 

  • An elevated reading, >300 mOsm/L, indicating loss of homeostasis, or
  • When the inter-eye difference is >8 mOsm/L, indicating instability of the tear film.

questions.text: You are conducting retrospective research on factors responsible for dry eye disorder.  As a part of your study, you are looking through the files in the clinic of dry eye patients. Which among the following patients would not be included in your study?

choices.text: A 26 year old patient showing decreased levels of lactoferrin in tear samples
A 20 year old patient showing tear film break up at 18-20 seconds
A 24 year old patient showing A pattern stain in Rose bengal staining
A 22 year old patient showing Schirmer test tear strip wet upto 9 mm

questions.solution:
A patient with tear film break up at 18-20 seconds is considered to be normal. All the other patients have dry eye.

Tear film break-up (BUT) time is the interval between a complete blink and the appearance of a first randomly distributed dry spot on the cornea. It is an indicator of the adequacy of the mucin component of tears.

Inference:

  • 15-35 seconds - normal
  • < 10 seconds- unstable tear film

Other options:

Option A: Tear samples can be assayed for the presence of markers known to be decreased (e.g. lactoferrin) or elevated (e.g. matrix metalloproteinase-9) in dry eye. This is known as tear constituent measurement. 

Option C: A patient with A pattern on Rose Bengal staining has severe dry eye. 

Option D: A patient with 9mm wet Schirmer strip has moderate dry eye. 

Related Pearl: Tear film tests used for the diagnosis of dry eye

Schirmer test

Inference 

  • 15 mm: Normal
  • 5-10 mm: Moderate keratoconjunctivitis sicca (KCS)
  • < 5 mm: Severe KCS

Tear film break up test (TBUT)

Inference 

  • 15-35 seconds: Normal
  • < 10 seconds: Unstable tear film

Rose Bengal staining

Inference

  • A pattern: Confluent staining → Severe KCS
  • B pattern: Extensive staining → Moderate KCS
  • C pattern: Fine punctate stains → Mild KCS

Tear osmolarity test

Abnormal osmolarity is defined by 

  • An elevated reading, >300 mOsm/L, indicating loss of homeostasis, or
  • When the inter-eye difference is >8 mOsm/L, indicating instability of the tear film.

questions.text: The findings of a test done in a patient under evaluation for dry eye are shown below. Identify the test.
questions.solution:
The image above depicts lacrimal scintigraphy.

Lacrimal scintigraphy (dacryoscintigraphy) is used to assess the lacrimal drainage function. A radioactive tracer (technetium-99m) is instilled into the conjunctival sac. Its path is then visualised with an Anger gamma camera. It is useful for the evaulation of watering eye. 

Other tests for evaluation of watering eye include regurgitation test, syringing, fluorescein dye disappearance test (FDDT), Jones dye test and dacryocystography.

Other options: 

Option A: In regurgitation test, steady pressure with the index finger is applied above the medial palpebral ligament. 

Option B: In dacryocystography, a radioopaque material is inserted into the lacrimal sac, following which X-rays are taken. 

Option C: The image shows the Jones dye test.

questions.text: What is the site of blockage in congenital dacryocystitis?
questions.solution:
The site of blockage in congenital dacryocystitis is the nasolacrimal duct. 

Congenital dacryocystitis occurs due to the stasis of secretions in the lacrimal sac due to congenital blockage in the nasolacrimal duct. Membranous occlusion at its lower end near the valve of Hasner is the commonest cause.

The image below shows a neonate with congenital dacryocystitis.

questions.text: A mother noticed the following finding in her 3-month-old child. There is a history of watering  and discharge from his right eye since birth. Which of the following is the best next step in the treatment?
questions.solution:
The image showing  right-sided swelling in the lacrimal sac area along with watering of the eye is suggestive of congenital dacryocystitis. Treatment for a 3-month-old child includes sac massage with topical antibiotics.

Congenital dacryocystitis is chronic inflammation of the lacrimal sac in newborn infants. It occurs due to congenital blockage of the nasolacrimal duct. More than 90% of patients with undergo spontaneous resolution by 1 year of age.

Treatment of congenital dacryocystitis depends on the age of the child:

  • Less than 9 months: Massaging (Crigler’s massage which increases the hydrostatic pressure within the sac) and antibiotic eye drops
  • 9 months to 4 years: Probing
  • Older children (> 4 years): Dacryocystorhinostomy (DCR) gives the best result. In DCR, an opening is made into the nasal cavity from the lacrimal sac.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man presents with watering from the right eye for 1 year. Syringing revealed a patent drainage system. Rest of the ocular examination was normal. A provisional diagnosis of lacrimal pump failure was made. Which of the following test will help in the confirmation of the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Lacrimal pump failure can be confirmed with dacryoscintigraphy.

Lacrimal pump failure means an inability of the lid muscles to push tears towards the punctum for drainage. It is also called functional obstruction and may be secondary to lower lid laxity or orbicularis muscle weakness (eg. facial nerve palsy. It is confirmed by dacryoscintigraphy, in which a radioactive tracer (technetium-99m) is instilled into the conjunctival sac and its path visualised with an Anger gamma camera. An atonic lacrimal sac is seen. 

Note: In cases of partial obstruction of the lacrimal apparatus, forced injection of fluid into the canalicular system (dacryocystography) can overcome the obstruction sites and point to a diagnosis of lacrimal pump failure. Thus, dacryoscintigraphy is better for the confirmation of lacrimal pump failure.

questions.text: A 55-year-old woman is being counseled for surgery for her long-standing dacryocystitis. Which of the following is the surgery of choice?
questions.solution:
The treatment of choice for chronic dacryocystitis is dacryocystorhinostomy (DCR)

DCR involves removal of the bone adjacent to the nasolacrimal sac and suturing the lacrimal sac with the lateral nasal mucosa. It re-establishes the lacrimal drainage and is hence the preferred surgery for chronic darcyocystectomy. 

Chronic dacryocystitis is a long-standing inflammation of the lacrimal sac. Streptococcus hemolyticus and Staphylococcus aureus are the most common etiological agents. Initial treatment is with antibiotics and anti-inflammatory agents. Sequelae include lacrimal fistula formation and mucocele formation, which when infected, leads to pyocele formation and finally lacrimal fibrosis. Treatment of lacrimal sac fibrosis is dacryocystectomy. Treatment of lacrimal fistula is dacryocystorhinostomy (DCR).

questions.text: A patient with chronic dacryocystitis, refractory to the medical treatment, has been scheduled for dacryocystorhinostomy. Following the surgery, the sac would be draining into the _______.
questions.solution:
After dacryocystorhinostomy, the lacrimal sac drains into the middle meatus.

Dacryocystorhinostomy (DCR) surgery involves removal of the bone adjacent to the nasolacrimal sac and suturing the lacrimal sac with the lateral nasal mucosa. This allows tears to drain directly from the sac via a new low-resistance pathway into the middle meatus. 

Coagulase-negative staphylococci (CONS) and Staphylococcus aureus are the organisms responsible for the majority of chronic dacrocystitis cases. Chronic dacryocystitis can be treated with amoxyclav and third-generation cephalosporins.

questions.text: What is the most common ocular manifestation in mumps?
questions.solution:
The most common ocular manifestation in mumps is dacryocystadenitis.

Dacryocystadenitis, or inflammation of the lacrimal gland, is seen in mumps. It presents as a painful swelling in the lateral part of the upper lid.

questions.text: Which is the most common lacrimal gland tumor?
questions.solution:
Pleomorphic adenoma is the most common lacrimal gland tumor. It is also the most common epithelial tumor of the lacrimal gland.

Pleomorphic adenoma, or benign mixed tumor, presents commonly in middle age as a slowly progressive painless swelling in the upper outer quadrant of the eyelid. The bone is usually not invaded in these tumors. They are treated by surgical removal along with their intact pseudo-capsule.

Malignant tumors of the lacrimal gland such as adenoid cystic carcinoma (option A), mucoepidermoid carcinoma (option C) and malignant mixed tumor (option D) generally occur in the elderly with a short history of appearance, rapid progression and pain. These tumors also present in the upper eyelid and are known to invade the adjacent bones. Radical surgical procedures and high dose radiotherapy are necessary for the removal of the tumor. Adenoid cystic carcinoma is the most common malignant epithelial tumor of the lacrimal gland.  

Both malignant and benign tumors are known to push the eyeball downwards and inwards while restricting the upwards and outwards movement of the eyeball.

The most common epithelial tumors, in order of frequency, are as follows:

  1. Benign mixed tumor (BMT), also known as a pleomorphic adenoma (PA)
  2. Adenoid cystic carcinoma (ACC)
  3. Pleomorphic adenocarcinoma (ACA)
  4. Mucoepidermoid carcinoma
